title: How to Do Chroma Key on Adobe Premiere Pro

steps.title: Select New Project if you want to start from scratch.
steps.content: Select New Project if you want to start from scratch. Or, open an existing project if you plan on adding chroma key to a composition you've already made.

steps.title: Just drag and drop it into the timeline.
steps.content: Just drag and drop it into the timeline. This can also just be Premiere's default background colour.

steps.title: For optimal effectiveness, they will always have a flat-colored background.
steps.content: For optimal effectiveness, they will always have a flat-colored background. This is commonly green, hence why the effect is also known as 'green screening.' Drop these clips onto the timeline above the background.

steps.title: Keep adjusting until you are satisfied with its size and position.
steps.content: Keep adjusting until you are satisfied with its size and position. If it will be a full-screen effect (like this clip of falling leaves), resize until it completely covers the screen.

steps.title: Make sure you are in the Effects tab (indicated at the top).
steps.content: Make sure you are in the Effects tab (indicated at the top). There should be an 'effects' search bar on the right. Inside, type key . There will be many different effects, but Ultra Key is the most effective one.

steps.title: On the left, the ultra key settings will appear in the effect menu.
steps.content: On the left, the ultra key settings will appear in the effect menu.

steps.title: It will now transform your cursor into a color selector.
steps.content: It will now transform your cursor into a color selector. Click on a green (or plain colour bg) part of the clip. You will notice that most of the green will disappear.

steps.title: Check to see if you are satisfied with the key.
steps.content: Check to see if you are satisfied with the key. If it looks messy or it doesn't look natural, you can tweak it with the settings. Some tweaks you can do include altering how aggressive color removal is and the saturation/hue of the clip. Play around until you are happy with it.

steps.title: Once you are done, you can export the project or continue editing.
steps.content: Once you are done, you can export the project or continue editing.
